chapters.title: 第一章：上学的第一天
chapters.text:
我叫爱琪。今天是星期四，是我来这个学校上学的第一天。这个学校里的学生不多。在这个学校上学的学生们，都要住在学校里边，我也一样。在上课的时候，老师请我到前边介绍我的名字和爱好。

爱琪：“同学们，早上好！我的名字叫爱琪，你们叫我小爱也行。我喜欢唱歌，也喜欢看电影。我不喜欢读书。很高兴认识你们！我想要和你们做好朋友！”

我还想再介绍一些我的事：我的家在……我常常去的商场是……我最喜欢吃的东西是……

这些，我都不记得了。

来这个学校前的事，我都不记得了！

en_sentences.en: My name is Aiqi.
Today is Thursday, and it's my first day studying at this school.
There aren't many students at this school.
All the students who study here live at the school, and I do too.
During class, the teacher asked me to go to the front to introduce my name and hobbies.
Aiqi: “Good morning, classmates!”
My name is Aiqi; you can call me Xiao Ai too.
I like singing, and I also like watching movies.
I don't like studying.
Nice to meet you!
I want to be friends with you all!
I also wanted to introduce more about myself—where my home is, the mall I often go to, and what food I like most... but I don't remember any of it.
I don't remember anything from before I came to this school!

chapters.title: 第二章：第一个朋友
chapters.text:
下课后，有一个女生和我说话。她说她的名字是诗启，两个多月前来到了这个学校。她喜欢看电影，喜欢听歌，还喜欢唱歌。她说她想和我做朋友。我们有一样的爱好，我也喜欢她。诗启是我在学校里认识的第一个好朋友。

学校里的事，我都和诗启一起做。早饭、午饭、晚饭，我们两个人都在一起吃。上课的时候，我们坐在一起；下课的时候，我们一起玩儿。晚上睡觉前，我们会一起唱喜欢的歌。能和诗启做朋友，我真的很高兴！

en_sentences.en: After class, a girl talked to me.
She said her name is Shiqi, and she came to this school more than two months ago.
She likes watching movies, listening to songs, and singing.
She said she wants to be friends with me.
We have the same hobbies, and I like her too.
Shiqi is the first good friend I met at this school.
At school, I do things together with Shiqi.
For breakfast, lunch, and dinner, the two of us eat together.
In class we sit together; after class we play together.
Before going to sleep at night, we sing songs we like together.
Being friends with Shiqi makes me really happy!

chapters.title: 第三章：不能做的事
chapters.text:
我们一个星期要上五天的课，从星期一到星期五。在星期六和星期日的时候，我们休息，不用上课。

在不用上课的这些时间里，我很想和诗启一起出去玩儿。我知道，在学校的东边有一个电影院，我想和诗启一起去那里看电影。我还知道，在电影院的北边有一个饭店，我想和诗启一起去那里吃东西。这些都是我在学校里的地图上看到的地方。

我也知道，我们不能去。在学校里，有一些我们不能做的事：没有老师和我们一起的时候，我们就不能出学校。我们也不能用手机和电脑。

en_sentences.en: We have classes five days a week, from Monday to Friday.
On Saturdays and Sundays, we rest and don’t have class.
During this time with no classes, I really want to go out and have fun with Shiqi.
I know there is a movie theater on the east side of the school, and I want to go there with Shiqi to watch a movie.
I also know there is a restaurant north of the theater, and I want to go there with Shiqi to eat.
These are places I saw on the school map.
But I also know we can’t go.
At school, there are things we are not allowed to do: when no teacher is with us, we can’t leave the school.
We also can’t use phones or computers.

chapters.title: 第四章：“都很好”
chapters.text:
今天是星期六，老师说要带我们一起去商场买东西，我很高兴。诗启准备买一个新书包。我准备买一个新本子。

到了商场后，老师给了我们每个人一百元钱。我们能用这一百元钱，去买喜欢的东西。我和诗启在商场里一块儿买东西，我们先去买书包。诗启拿了一个书包就要买。

爱琪：“你先等一会儿再买！你怎么在商店门口，不进来呢？商店里边还有很多别的书包呢，你快进来！”

诗启：“好的。”

爱琪：“你看！这个书包也很好看。”

诗启：“好，我就买这个。”

爱琪：“你还没看呢……还有这个！这两个书包，你喜欢哪个？”

诗启：“我觉得都很好。”

爱琪：“……”

最后，诗启买了我觉得好看的那个书包。诗启常常觉得什么都很好，我和她不一样。我有喜欢的东西，也有不喜欢的东西。

在商场里，我还看到了两个人……

en_sentences.en: Today is Saturday. The teacher said he would take us to the mall to buy things, and I was very happy.
Shiqi planned to buy a new backpack.
I planned to buy a new notebook.
After we arrived at the mall, the teacher gave each of us 100 yuan.
We could use this 100 yuan to buy things we liked.
Shiqi and I shopped together in the mall, and first we went to buy a backpack.
Shiqi picked up a backpack and was about to buy it.
Aiqi: “Wait a moment before you buy!”
Why are you standing at the shop entrance and not coming in?
There are many other backpacks inside—come in quickly!”
Shiqi: “Okay.”
Aiqi: “Look!”
This backpack looks nice too.
Shiqi: “Okay, I’ll buy this one.”
Aiqi: “You haven’t even looked yet… and there’s this one too!”
Between these two backpacks, which one do you like?
Shiqi: “I think they’re both good.”
In the end, Shiqi bought the backpack that I thought looked good.
Shiqi often thinks everything is good, but I’m not the same as her.
There are things I like, and things I don’t like.
At the mall, I also saw two people…

chapters.title: 第五章：家人？
chapters.text:
在商场里，我看到了两个人。那是一个女人和一个小男孩儿，我听到了他们说的话。小男孩儿说：“妈妈，我想买这个书包。”那个女人回答：“好。”

听了小男孩儿的话，我想到了我的妈妈。我的妈妈是谁？她现在在哪儿？我都不记得了。我还有别的家人吗？我的家人在哪里？我也不知道。

我走到诗启的旁边。

爱琪：“诗启，你家有几口人？”

诗启：“我不知道。”

爱琪：“你的妈妈是谁？她现在在哪儿？”

诗启：“我也不知道。”

爱琪：“来这里上学前，你住在哪里？”

诗启：“我不记得了……”

诗启也不记得这些事，真的是太奇怪了！我们是生病了吗？怎么都不记得来学校前的事了？也都不记得我们的家人？

en_sentences.en: At the mall, I saw two people.
It was a woman and a little boy, and I heard what they said.
The little boy said, 'Mom, I want to buy this backpack.'
The woman replied, 'Okay.'
After hearing him, I thought of my mom.
Who is my mom?
Where is she now?
I don’t remember.
Do I have other family members?
Where is my family?
I don’t know either.
I walked over to Shiqi.
Aiqi: 'Shiqi, how many people are in your family?'
Shiqi: 'I don’t know.'
Aiqi: 'Who is your mom?'
Where is she now?
Shiqi: 'I don’t know either.'
Aiqi: 'Before you came here to study, where did you live?'
Shiqi: 'I don’t remember…' She doesn’t remember these things either—this is really too strange!
Are we sick?
How is it that we don’t remember anything from before coming to school?
And we don’t remember our families either?

chapters.title: 第六章：“对”
chapters.text:
我和诗启不住在一个房间里。今天下课后，我去了诗启的房间，和她一起学习。

爱琪：“诗启，你来这个学校几个月了？”

诗启：“到下个星期就三个月了。”

爱琪：“都快三个月了！我来这里还不到一个星期。我们学校有十个老师吧？诗启，你觉得哪个老师最好？”

诗启：“我觉得老师们都很好。”

爱琪：“我很喜欢我们的汉语老师，我觉得汉语老师比外语老师好。汉语课很好玩儿，有时候，老师会给我们放电影。外语课太难了，很多外语课本里的课文我都不会读。”

诗启：“对，那些课文太难了。”

爱琪：“你真的觉得难吗？上课的时候，我听见你都会读。你觉得我们的生活老师，王老师好不好？”

诗启：“他是个很好的人。”

爱琪：“我觉得他很凶。”

诗启：“对，他也很凶。”

诗启还是一样，常常用“不知道”和“对”……来回答我。

en_sentences.en: Shiqi and I don't live in the same room.
After class today, I went to Shiqi's room and studied with her.
Aiqi: 'Shiqi, how many months have you been at this school?'
Shiqi: 'By next week it will be three months.'
Aiqi: 'Almost three months!'
I've been here less than a week.
Our school has ten teachers, right?
Shiqi, which teacher do you think is the best?'
Shiqi: 'I think all the teachers are good.'
Aiqi: 'I really like our Chinese teacher.'
I think the Chinese teacher is better than the foreign-language teacher.
Chinese class is really fun.
Sometimes the teacher plays movies for us.
Foreign-language class is too hard; I can't read a lot of the texts in the foreign-language textbook.
Shiqi: 'Yes, those texts are too hard.'
Aiqi: 'Do you really think it's hard?'
In class, I heard you could read them all.
What do you think of our life teacher, Teacher Wang—good or not?'
Shiqi: 'He's a very good person.'
Aiqi: 'I think he's very strict.'
Shiqi: 'Yes, he's also very strict.'
Shiqi was still the same, often answering me with 'I don't know' and 'yes'...

chapters.title: 第七章：消失的朋友
chapters.text:
今天是星期二，诗启没有来上课。老师没有告诉我们诗启怎么了。我问别的同学诗启去哪儿了，他们也都说不知道。没有诗启的这一天，我做什么事都不高兴。

放学后，我马上去诗启的房间找她，想看看她是不是病了。我来到诗启的房间后，没有看到她。她的房间里很干净，床上什么东西都没有。她的书、衣服、杯子、书包……她的东西都没有了。诗启怎么了？她去哪儿了？她怎么没有告诉我就走了？她还会回来吗？

en_sentences.en: Today is Tuesday, and Shiqi didn't come to class.
The teacher didn't tell us what happened to Shiqi.
I asked other classmates where Shiqi went, but they all said they didn't know.
Without Shiqi, I wasn't happy doing anything that day.
After school, I immediately went to Shiqi's room to look for her, to see if she was sick.
When I got to her room, I didn't see her.
Her room was very clean, and there was nothing on the bed.
Her books, clothes, cup, backpack... all of her things were gone.
What happened to Shiqi?
Where did she go?
Why did she leave without telling me?
Will she come back?

chapters.title: 第八章：寻找她
chapters.text:
第二天，我一到学校就去找诗启。我去了教室、走廊、食堂，也去了她的房间，可是哪里都没有她。我问了老师，老师只说她今天不在，让我回去上课。

下课后，我又去问同学。有人说没见过她，有人说不记得这个名字。我心里很难受：昨天她还在，今天怎么就不见了？

晚上，我一个人坐在床上，想了很久。诗启真的来过吗？如果她来过，为什么大家都不记得？我决定继续找下去。

en_sentences.en: The next day, as soon as I arrived at school, I went to look for Shiqi.
I went to the classroom, the hallway, and the cafeteria, and I also went to her room, but she was nowhere.
I asked the teacher, and the teacher only said she wasn't here today and told me to go back to class.
After class, I went to ask other classmates again.
Some said they hadn't seen her; some said they didn't remember that name.
I felt awful: she was here yesterday—how could she be gone today?
At night, I sat on the bed alone and thought for a long time.
Did Shiqi really come here?
If she did, why doesn't everyone remember?
I decided to keep searching.

chapters.title: 第九章：变化
chapters.text:
没有诗启的日子，一切都不一样了。上课的时候，我总是看向她以前坐的地方。那个位子现在空着，好像从来没有人坐过。

我发现了一些小变化：她的名字不在名单上，她的床也不见了。就像她从来没有在这个学校生活过一样。

我开始怀疑自己：是不是我记错了？可是我还记得我们一起吃饭、一起唱歌。我知道，这些不是假的。

en_sentences.en: Without Shiqi, everything felt different.
During class, I always looked toward where she used to sit.
That seat is empty now, as if no one ever sat there.
I noticed some small changes: her name isn't on the list, and her bed is gone too.
It's as if she never lived at this school.
I started to doubt myself: did I remember wrong?
But I still remember us eating together and singing together.
I know this isn't fake.

chapters.title: 第十章：新朋友
chapters.text:
几天后，班里来了一个新学生。老师让她坐在诗启以前的位子上。她对我笑，说她刚来这个学校，什么都不熟。

下课时，她来和我说话，问我学校的事。她说她也不记得来这里以前的生活。

我一边和她聊天，一边想起诗启。她们不一样，可是有一点很像：她们都没有过去。我不知道该不该再交朋友，但我也不想再一个人。

en_sentences.en: A few days later, a new student came to our class.
The teacher had her sit in the seat Shiqi used to sit in.
She smiled at me and said she had just come to this school and wasn't familiar with anything.
After class, she came to talk to me and asked about the school.
She said she also didn't remember her life before coming here.
While I chatted with her, I kept thinking of Shiqi.
They are different, but there's one thing that's similar: neither of them has a past.
I don't know if I should make friends again, but I also don't want to be alone anymore.

chapters.title: 第十一章：我不知道
chapters.text:
新同学叫小文。她的眼睛很亮，说话也很轻。可是我问她什么，她常常回答：我不知道。

下课的时候，我和她一起去食堂。我问她，你来这个学校多久了。她说：我不知道。我又问她，你住在哪个房间。她还是说：我不知道。

我觉得奇怪：怎么会什么都不知道。我问她，来这里以前你记得什么吗。她想了想，摇摇头，说她不记得。

听到这些话，我心里一冷。诗启以前也常常这样回答我。难道在这个学校里，所有人都会慢慢变成这样吗？

en_sentences.en: The new classmate is called Xiaowen.
Her eyes are bright, and she speaks softly.
But no matter what I asked, she often answered: I don't know.
After class, I went to the cafeteria with her.
I asked her how long she had been at this school.
She said: I don't know.
I asked again which room she lived in.
She still said: I don't know.
I felt it was strange—how could she not know anything?
I asked what she remembered from before coming here.
She thought for a moment, shook her head, and said she didn't remember.
Hearing this, my heart went cold.
Shiqi used to answer me like this too.
In this school, will everyone slowly become like this?

chapters.title: 第一章：最努力的女孩
chapters.text: 丝雨刻苦努力，是最美也最聪明的女孩。她的男友小卡英勇帅气，猫咪Kiki又胖又黏人。三人互相照顾，学习、冒险、做饭、看星星，烦恼都会消失。他们笑着说，这就是他们的幸福“zoogether”。每天都充满温暖与希望。

chapters.title: 第一章：路口
chapters.text:
我住的小镇很安静。镇外有一条小路，路很窄，两边都是树。大家叫它“北边的路”。白天有人走过，可是很少。

我第一次听说这条路，是在食堂。一个同学小声说：“别一个人去那边。”我问他为什么，他只摇头，说：“去过的人，不会回来。”

我不信。我问老师，老师笑着说：“别想太多，回去学习。”我又问生活老师王老师，他看了我一眼，说：“不要问。”

第二天是星期六，我们不用上课。我和同学在操场玩儿，可是我一直在想那条路。中午以后，我一个人走到学校门口。门口有地图，地图上没有那条路。

我沿着围墙往北走，越走越安静。风吹过树叶，声音像有人在说话。路口有一块旧牌子，上面写着：禁止进入。可是牌子很破，好像很久没人管。

我站在路口，没有进去。我看见地上有一只小鞋子，干净得像刚放下。旁边还有一点白纸，上面只有两个字：回来。

我心里一冷，赶快把纸捡起来放进口袋。我回头看学校，学校就在那儿，可是我突然觉得离得很远。

晚上回到宿舍，我把那张纸拿出来。字还在，可是纸背面多了一个淡淡的手印。我正想再看清楚，灯突然闪了一下。

门外有人轻轻敲门。没有人说话，只听见一声很低的笑。

en_sentences.en: My town is very quiet.
Outside the town there is a small road. It is narrow, with trees on both sides.
Everyone calls it “the north road.”
People walk there in the daytime, but not many.
The first time I heard about this road was in the cafeteria.
A classmate whispered, “Don’t go over there alone.”
I asked why, but he only shook his head and said, “People who go there don’t come back.”
I didn’t believe it.
I asked a teacher. The teacher smiled and said, “Don’t think too much. Go back and study.”
I asked our life teacher, Teacher Wang. He glanced at me and said, “Don’t ask.”
The next day was Saturday, and we didn’t have class.
I played on the playground with classmates, but I kept thinking about that road.
After noon, I walked alone to the school gate.
At the gate there is a map, but that road isn’t on it.
I walked north along the wall. The farther I went, the quieter it became.
The wind moved through the leaves, and it sounded like someone was talking.
At the road entrance there was an old sign that said: No Entry.
But the sign was broken, like nobody had cared for it in a long time.
I stood at the entrance and didn’t go in.
I saw a small shoe on the ground, clean as if it had just been set down.
Next to it was a small piece of white paper with only two characters: “Come back.”
My heart went cold. I quickly picked up the paper and put it into my pocket.
I looked back at the school. It was right there, but suddenly it felt very far away.
That night in the dorm, I took the paper out.
The words were still there, but on the back was a faint handprint.
I was trying to see it clearly when the light suddenly flickered.
Someone gently knocked on the door.
No one spoke. I only heard a very quiet laugh.

chapters.title: 没有封面的书
chapters.text:
我在旧书店里发现一本没有封面的书。翻开第一页，里面写着：
    “如果你看到这行字，请把书带走。”
    
我抬头看了看四周，没有人。于是我买下它，走出门时，风把书页吹开，露出一张夹着的照片：
    照片里的人，竟然是我。

en_sentences.en: I found an old book without its cover in a used bookstore.
Opening the first page, it says: "If you're reading this line, please take the book with you."
I looked up and around, but there was no one.
So I bought it, and as I stepped out of the door, the wind blew open the book pages to reveal a photo tucked inside: The person in the photo was actually me.

chapters.title: 雨中的小咖啡店
chapters.text: 昨天我在雨中迷路，走进一家小咖啡店。老板笑着给我一杯热茶，说：“慢慢来，路会找到你。”我坐了一会儿，雨停了，心也安静了。

en_sentences.en: Yesterday, I got lost in the rain and stumbled upon a small coffee shop.
The boss smilingly handed me a cup of hot tea and said, "Take it slow, the road will find you."
I sat for a while, and then the rain stopped, my heart grew calm as well."

chapters.title: 懒猫Kiki的冒险
chapters.text:
Kiki是一只又胖又懒的猫，平时最爱睡觉和吃鱼。一天中午，它发现窗外有一只小鸟叼着闪闪发光的钥匙飞走了。Kiki本想继续睡，可好奇心推着它跳下窗台，慢慢跟了上去。
它穿过小巷，爬过矮墙，第一次跑得气喘吁吁。小鸟把钥匙掉在一棵老树下，Kiki叼起钥匙，发现树洞里藏着一盒温热的猫罐头。
Kiki吃得心满意足，拖着钥匙回家，从此每天仍然很懒，但心里多了一点：原来世界，也会奖励一次小小的勇敢。

en_sentences.en: Kiki is a plump and lazy cat who loves sleeping and eating fish.
One midday, it discovered that outside the window, there was a small bird flying away with a shiny key in its beak.
Kiki wanted to keep sleeping, but curiosity pushed it to jump down from the windowsill and slowly follow along.
It dashed through the alley, climbed over the low wall for the first time, breathlessly panting.
A little bird dropped its key under an old tree, and Kiki picked it up. Upon examining the hollow of the tree, she found a warm can of cat food hidden there.

Kiki ate to her heart's content and dragged her key back home, whereupon she remained as lazy as ever every day thereafter. But inside, there was a new addition: she knew that the world could reward even the smallest act of bravery.

chapters.title: 第一章：我们的农场
chapters.text:
农场很大，也很安静。
早上，太阳出来，地上有光。晚上，风从田里来，带着草的味道。
人每天来，也每天走。他们做事，我们看着。
我们听得懂人，可是人听不懂我们。我们只能跟彼此说话。

黑狗住在房子前面。他白天看路，晚上听声音。
他说：“这里要安全。我们在这里，就要看着。”
他不常笑，也不爱说多的话。可是大家都知道，他会保护我们。

白猫住在旧仓房的屋顶上。他喜欢高的地方。
他看得远，也看得久。
他常常笑，说一些听起来不重要的话。
他说：“变化不是坏事。也许，会更有意思。”
有时他还会说：“也许有一天，我们都会被吃掉。”
大家听了，不知道他是在开玩笑，还是在说真的。

老牛住在牛棚里。他走得慢，说话也慢。
他说：“以前，这里不是这样的。”
他记得很多过去的事，可是我们不知道他记得多少。

马在田边。她喜欢走，喜欢看远的地方。
她常说：“如果这里变了，我们可以走。”
她的眼睛很亮，好像一直在找路。

母鸡和公鸡住在鸡舍里。
母鸡最担心。她看着小鸡，说：“只要它们安全，别的都不重要。”
公鸡每天早上叫。他说：“这是我们的地方。”
他说话很大声，好像声音可以让世界不变。

猪住在水边。他关心吃，也关心今天。
他说：“只要有吃的，我们就活得下去。”
他不常想以后。

羊们在田里一起走。它们常常跟着别人。
它们说：“大家在一起，就安全。”

鸭子在河里。它们知道水的路，也知道外面的世界。
它们说：“河那边，有别的地方。”

小鸟常常飞来飞去。它看到很多东西。
它说：“我看见人带来新的东西，也看见他们带走一些东西。”
可是它不知道为什么。

鹿不住在农场里。它住在山边。
有时它会来，站在远处看我们。
它很安静，好像不想被看见。

我们每天这样生活。
人来，我们看着；人走，我们还在。
我们吃，我们睡，我们说话。

有一天，白猫坐在屋顶上，看着路。
他笑了一下，说：“你们不觉得，最近有点不一样吗？”
黑狗抬起头，说：“哪里不一样？”
白猫没有马上回答，只是看着远处。

老牛慢慢地说：“我也觉得，风不一样了。”
马看向路的尽头。母鸡把小鸡拉近。
小鸟飞到黑狗的肩上，说：“我看见人带来了新的声音。”
黑狗听了一会儿，说：“不管怎样，我们要小心。”

白猫跳下来，走到黑狗身边。
他低声说：“别这么紧张。也许，只是变化。”
黑狗看着他：“你真的觉得没事吗？”
白猫没有回答。

太阳慢慢下去。农场还是那个农场。
可是我们心里，都知道了一件事：
好像，有什么要开始了。

en_sentences.en: The farm is large and very quiet.
In the morning, the sun comes out, and the ground is lit.
In the evening, the wind comes from the fields, carrying the scent of grass.
People come and go every day.
They do their thing, and we watch.
We can understand people, but people can't understand us.
We can only talk to each other.
The black dog lives in front of the house.
He watches the road by day and listens for sounds at night.
He said, "This place must be safe."
We’re here, and we’re going to watch.
He doesn't laugh often, and he doesn't say much.
But everyone knows that he will protect us.
The white cat lives on the roof of the old warehouse.
He likes high places.
He can see far, and he can keep watching for a long time.
He often laughs, saying things that sound unimportant.
He said, "Change isn't a bad thing."
Perhaps it would be more interesting.
Sometimes he would also say, "Perhaps one day we'll all be eaten."
Everyone listened, not knowing whether he was joking or telling the truth.
The old ox lives in the cattle shed.
He walks slowly and speaks slowly.
He said, "This place wasn't like this before."
He remembers a lot about the past, but we don’t know how much he remembers.
The horse is at the edge of the field.
She likes walking and likes looking at faraway places.
She often says, "If things change around here, we can leave."
Her eyes were bright, as if she were always looking for a way.
The hen and the rooster live in the chicken coop.
The hen worries the most.
She looked at the chicks and said, "As long as they're safe, nothing else matters."
The rooster crows every morning.
He said, "This is our place."
He speaks very loudly, as if his voice could keep the world from changing.
The pig lives by the water's edge.
He cares about what he eats, and he cares about today as well.
He said, "As long as there is food, we can survive."
He doesn't often think about the future.
The sheep are walking together in the field.
They often tag along with others.
They say, "When we're all together, we're safe."
A duck is in the river.
They know the path that water takes, and they know the world beyond.
They say, "There are other places beyond the river."
The little bird often flies back and forth.
It saw a lot of things.
It says: "I've seen people bring in new things, and I've seen them take away some things."
But it doesn't know why.
Deer do not live on the farm.
It lives on the mountainside.
Sometimes it comes and watches us from a distance.
It's very quiet, as if it doesn't want to be seen.
We live like this every day.
When people arrive, we watch; when they leave, we stay.
We eat, we sleep, we talk.
One day, a white cat sat on the roof, watching the road.
He smiled a little and said, "Don't you think things have been a bit different lately?"
The black dog lifted its head and said, "What's different?"
The white cat didn't answer right away; it just stared into the distance.
The old ox spoke slowly, "I also feel that the wind has changed."
The horse looked toward the end of the road.
The hen pulls the chick closer.
The little bird flew onto the black dog's shoulder and said, "I see that people have brought a new sound."
The black dog listened for a while and said, "No matter what, we must be careful."
The white cat jumped down and walked over to the black dog's side.
He whispered, "Don't be so nervous."
Perhaps it's just a change.
The black dog looked at him and asked, “Do you really think you’re okay?”
The white cat didn't answer.
The sun slowly sets.
It's still the same old farm.
But deep down, we all knew one thing: it seemed like something was about to begin.

chapters.title: 第二章：不再只是变化
chapters.text:
清晨的农场比往常更安静。风还是从田里来，可是味道变了，不只是草的味道，还有一种说不清的气息。
白猫站在屋顶边上，看着远处的路。他没有像平时那样开玩笑，只是眯着眼睛，一动不动。

黑狗在院子里走来走去。他走得不快，却很稳，像是在量每一块地。
他低声说：“我一晚上都没睡好。”
白猫笑了一下：“你什么时候睡得好过？”
黑狗没有接话，只是看向路口。

小鸟从天上飞下来，落在木桩上。
它说：“今天早上，人来得比平时早。他们带了很多东西。”
“什么东西？”黑狗问。
“不是吃的，也不是水。是冷的东西，还有很大的声音。”
白猫看着它：“你确定不是你听错了？”
小鸟摇头：“我不会听错。”

老牛慢慢地走出牛棚。他看了看天空，又看了看地。
“风变了。”他说，“不是天气的问题。”
猪正在水边喝水，听到这句话，抬起头：“你们总是说风变了。可我觉得，只要还有吃的，就没什么大问题。”
白猫转过身，对猪说：“如果有一天，连你最在乎的东西都不在了呢？”
猪愣了一下，没有回答。

马站在田边，看着远方。
“我昨晚没有睡。”她说，“我一直在想，如果有一天，这里不再是我们的地方，我们要去哪儿？”
羊们靠在一起，小声说：“也许不会有那一天。也许大家只是想太多了。”
白猫轻轻地笑了一声：“也许吧。可有些事情，不是你不想，就不会发生。”

中午前，人真的来了。
他们没有看我们，也没有说话，只是把一些东西放在地上，又在远处讨论。
我们听不懂他们的话，只能看见他们的手势、他们的脸色，还有那些陌生的器械。
黑狗站得很直，眼睛一刻也没有离开他们。
母鸡把小鸡拉到身后，小声说：“不要乱跑。”

一阵很重的声音响起来，像是从地里出来的。
鸭子被吓得拍水：“这不是河的声音。”
小鸟飞到高处，回来时说：“他们在地上画线。”
“画线做什么？”羊问。
白猫慢慢地说：“通常，线是用来分开东西的。”

老牛看着那条线，沉默了很久。
“以前，也有人画过线。”他说，“后来，有些地方就不再是我们的地方了。”
黑狗转向他：“你为什么现在才说？”
老牛摇头：“因为那时候，我也以为只是变化。”

鹿出现在田的尽头。它站在阴影里，没有靠近。
白猫注意到它，轻声说：“你不该来这里。”
鹿看着他，过了一会儿才说：“外面的世界，已经不是以前的样子了。”
黑狗走近一步：“什么意思？”
鹿没有直接回答，只是说：“有些路，一旦被画出来，就很难再消失。”

猪不耐烦地哼了一声：“你们说的都太复杂了。今天有没有吃的？有。那就够了。”
白猫看着它，语气出奇地平静：“有时候，问题不是今天有没有吃的，而是明天你还能不能站在这里。”

黄昏的时候，人走了。
他们带走了一些东西，也留下了一些东西。
农场看起来还是原来的样子，可每个人心里都明白，有些东西已经被改变了。

黑狗坐在院子中间，像是在守着什么。
“从今天开始，晚上不要单独走。”他说，“不管你觉得有没有危险。”
母鸡点头，羊们靠得更紧。
马没有说话，只是看向远方。

白猫回到屋顶上，望着那条新画出来的线。
他轻声说：“我本来以为，这只是变化。”
黑狗抬头看他：“现在呢？”
白猫沉默了一会儿，嘴角还是那样的笑，却少了轻松。
“现在我觉得，”他说，“这不是为了让世界更有意思的变化。”

夜色慢慢落下。
农场很安静，可这种安静，不再让人安心。

en_sentences.en: The farm is quieter in the early morning than usual.
The wind still comes from the fields, but the scent has changed. It’s not just the smell of grass—there’s also an indescribable aura.
A white cat stands on the edge of the roof, watching the road in the distance.
He wasn't joking around the way he usually did. He just squinted, staying perfectly still.
A black dog is pacing back and forth in the yard.
He doesn't walk fast, but he's very steady, as if measuring out every inch of ground.
He whispered, "I didn't sleep well at all last night."
The white cat smiled a little and said, "When did you sleep better?"
The black dog didn’t say a word; it just looked toward the intersection.
A small bird flew down from the sky and landed on a wooden stake.
It said, "This morning, people arrived earlier than usual."
They brought a lot of things.
What is this?
The black dog asks.
It's not edible, and it's not water either.
It's a cold thing, and there's a very loud noise.
The white cat looked at it and asked, “Are you sure you didn’t mishear?”
The little bird shook its head: "I heard that correctly."
The old cow slowly walked out of the barn.
He glanced at the sky, then glanced at the ground.
The wind has changed.
He said, "It's not a matter of the weather."
A pig was drinking by the water when it heard those words and raised its head: "You all always say that the wind has changed."
But I think as long as there's food, there won't be any big problems.
The white cat turned around and said to the pig, "What if one day, even the thing you care about the most isn't there?"
The pig froze for a moment and didn't answer.
The horse stood at the edge of the field, gazing into the distance.
I didn't sleep last night.
She said, "I've been thinking: if one day this place isn't our home anymore, where would we go?"
The sheep huddled together and whispered, "Perhaps that day will never come."
Maybe everyone is just overthinking.
The white cat laughed softly. "Perhaps."
But there are some things that won’t happen just because you want them.
The person actually arrived before noon.
They didn't look at us or say anything; they simply placed some things on the ground and spoke from a distance.
We can't understand what they're saying; we can only see their gestures, their expressions, and those unfamiliar instruments.
The black dog stood upright, its eyes never leaving them for a moment.
The hen pulled the chick behind her and whispered, "Don't wander off."
A heavy sound rang out, as if it came from the ground.
The duck, startled, slapped at the water: "That's not the sound of the river."
The little bird flew up to a high place, and when it returned it said, "They're drawing lines on the ground."
What are you drawing lines for?
The sheep asks.
The white cat spoke slowly: "Usually, lines are used to separate things."
Old Niu looked at that line and fell silent for a long time.
In the past, there were people who drew a line as well.
He said, "Later, some places were no longer ours."
The black dog turned toward him. "Why are you only saying it now?"
Old Ox shook his head: "At that time, I too thought it was just a change."
A deer appeared at the far end of the field.
It stood in the shadows, not coming closer.
The white cat noticed it and whispered, "You shouldn't have come here."
The deer looked at him, and after a moment it spoke, "The world outside is no longer the same as it used to be."
The black dog stepped closer and asked, "What do you mean?"
The deer didn’t answer directly; it simply said, “Some roads, once drawn, are hard to erase.”
The pig snorted impatiently, "What you're saying is all too complicated."
Is there anything to eat today?
Yes.
That's enough.
The white cat looked at it, its tone unusually calm: "Sometimes the question isn't whether there's food today, but whether you'll still be able to stand here tomorrow."
As dusk fell, people left.
They took some things away and left some behind.
The farm still looks the same as before, but everyone knows in their hearts that some things have already changed.
A black dog sat in the middle of the yard, as if guarding something.
Starting today, don’t go out alone at night.
He said, "Regardless of whether you think it's dangerous."
The hen nods, and the sheep press closer.
The horse didn't speak; it simply looked off into the distance.
The white cat climbed back onto the roof and gazed at the line that had just been drawn.
He whispered, "I originally thought this was only a change."
The black dog looked up at him and asked, “What now?”
The white cat was silent for a moment, its mouth still curved into that smile, but it was no longer at ease.
"Now I think," he said, "this isn't a change meant to make the world more interesting."
The night falls slowly.
The farm is very quiet, but this quiet no longer puts people at ease.

chapters.title: 第1章：回到河边
chapters.text:
我回到这个地方的时候，天已经快黑了。

车站还是那个车站，只是看起来更小了。墙上的字有些掉了漆，灯也比我记得的要黄。我站在门口，突然不知道该往哪边走。明明这条路我小时候走过无数次，可是现在，每一步都像是踩在别人的记忆里。

我带的东西不多，一个背包，一只旧箱子。箱子上有一道很浅的划痕，是很多年前留下的。我摸了一下那条痕，手指停了停，像是在确认这不是梦。

外面没有人等我。我也没有告诉太多人我会回来。说到底，我不是回来见谁的。我只是觉得——如果再不回来一次，我可能会永远错过某个答案。

我沿着路往镇里走。路两边的店铺关了大半，剩下的几家开着灯，里面的人影很慢，像是在和时间讨价还价。风从河那边吹来，带着潮湿的味道，也带着一种说不出的凉意。我闻到那味道时，心里忽然紧了一下。

河一直在那儿。它不急，也不慢，像一条习惯了沉默的线，把镇子分成两边。小时候我们总说，河那边是“另一边”，像是另外一个世界。我现在才明白，所谓“另一边”，有时候不是地理，而是人心里不愿意碰的地方。

走到桥头的时候，我停下来。桥上的木板换过了，栏杆也重新刷了漆，可是桥头那块石头还在。石头上有一道裂缝，像一条细细的嘴，永远不肯合上。小时候我总爱在这里坐一会儿，听水声，等天黑再回家。我记得那时候我不怕黑。现在我站在这里，却觉得背后好像有人在看我。

我回头，当然什么都没有。只有路灯下的一只狗。

它是黑色的，毛不长，眼睛却很亮。它站得不近不远，像是刻意保持距离。它没有叫，也没有摇尾巴，只是安静地看着我。我本来想绕开，可是它往前走了两步，又停下，像是在问：“你还记得我吗？”

我不认识它。我也不敢说我不认识。因为在这一刻，我突然意识到——在这个镇上，很多“我以为我不认识”的东西，其实都可能认识我。

“你是谁家的？”我低声问。

狗当然没有回答。它只是转过身，慢慢往镇子的方向走。我犹豫了一下，还是跟了上去。不是因为我喜欢狗，而是因为它走得很确定，像知道我要去哪里。

我们走过一条很窄的巷子，巷子尽头有一盏旧灯，灯下停着一辆三轮车。车旁边坐着一只白猫。

它把身体缩得很小，尾巴绕在前爪旁边，看起来像一团很干净的影子。听到脚步声，它抬起头，眼神很冷，却没有害怕。它看了黑狗一眼，又看了我一眼，像是在判断我是不是“该出现的人”。

我忍不住笑了一下：“现在连猫狗都来欢迎我了？”

白猫没有动。黑狗也没有动。那一刻，空气里有一种奇怪的安静，像是所有声音都在等我说错一句话。

我把笑收回去，轻声说：“我只是回来住几天。”

白猫眨了一下眼。那动作很慢，像是在说：“你以为你能决定只住几天？”

黑狗继续往前走。我走了两步，白猫也跳下车，跟在后面。它走得很轻，几乎没有声音。黑狗走得很稳，像在巡逻。我们三个谁都没有说话，可是我却觉得他们之间好像在交流一种我听不见的语言。

我忽然想起小时候的一件事。

那一年夏天特别热。我跟着大人去河边。有人在桥上争吵，声音很大。我记得我站得很远，可是我还是听见了自己的心跳。后来大人把我拉走，说不要看，不要问。回家的路上，我一直回头，可是河那边的树影越来越黑，像是把什么东西吞了进去。

我当时以为那只是大人的事，和我没有关系。可我也记得，从那天以后，家里有人变得很沉默。有人不再提起某个名字。有人开始很早就关门。河还是那条河，只是我们再也不随便去桥头坐着了。

现在，黑狗带着我走的方向，正是我小时候不敢去的那条路。

我停下脚步。黑狗回头看我。它的眼神不像一只普通的狗，更像一个在等我做决定的人。

“我不想去那边。”我说。

白猫站在一旁，尾巴轻轻一摆，像是在笑我。它没有出声，但那种轻微的动作比任何话都更刺。

黑狗没有催我，只是站着。过了几秒，它转身走到我脚边，用鼻子轻轻碰了一下我的裤脚，然后又往前走了一步。

那一下很轻，却像一只手。

我深吸了一口气，继续跟上去。

路越走越窄，两边的墙也越高。远处有一家亮着灯的小店，门口挂着一串风铃，风一吹，声音很清脆。我走近时，看见店里坐着一个老太太。

她抬起头，看见我，脸上没有惊讶，反而像早就知道我会来。她的眼睛很浑，却很稳。她看了看黑狗，又看了看白猫，最后才看向我。

“回来了？”她说。

我点头：“王奶奶……您还记得我？”

她笑了一下，笑得很短：“我当然记得。你走的时候，还没这么高。”

我不知道该怎么接。很多话堵在喉咙里，可是我说不出来。老太太也没有逼我，只是把手里的茶杯放下，看着我，好像在等我自己开口。

黑狗趴在门口，像守门。白猫跳到柜台边，坐得很端正，像是这家店的主人。王奶奶看着它们，眼神里没有意外，只有一种习惯了的平静。

她轻声说：“你终于还是回来了。”

“我只是……”我想说我只是路过，或者我只是想住几天，可是话到嘴边，变得很薄，很没用。

王奶奶没有笑我。她只是慢慢地说：“河那边的事，你一直没忘，对吗？”

我手指一紧。茶杯里的热气往上升，模糊了我的视线。我想否认，可是我发现自己连否认的力气都没有。

黑狗在门口动了一下。白猫的尾巴垂下来，轻轻扫过柜台，像在提醒我：别说太多，别说错。

我看着王奶奶，过了很久才说：“我回来……是想知道，那天到底发生了什么。”

王奶奶没有立刻回答。她把目光移向窗外，窗外正对着河的方向。夜色已经压下来，河面看不清，只剩下一点点反光，像有人把一把刀藏在水里。

她低声说：“你想知道答案，就别只站在这边。”

我心里一沉。黑狗抬起头，看着我。白猫的眼睛在灯光下像两点冷光。

我明白了。

我回来的第一天，就已经被带到桥边了。

en_sentences.en: By the time I got back to this place, it was almost dark.
It's still the same station; it just looks smaller.
The letters on the wall have peeled paint in places, and the lamp is yellower than I remember.
I stood at the doorway and suddenly I didn’t know which way to go.
I used to walk this road countless times when I was a child, but now every step feels like I'm treading on someone else's memories.
I didn't bring much, just a backpack and an old suitcase.
There's a faint scratch on the box that's been there for many years.
I touched that mark, my finger pausing for a moment, as if to confirm that this wasn't a dream.
There's no one waiting for me outside.
I didn't tell too many people that I would be back.
At the end of the day, I'm not back to see anyone.
I just feel that if I don’t come back one more time, I might miss out on an answer forever.
I walk along the road toward the town.
Most of the shops on both sides of the road have closed. The few that remain are lit, and the figures inside move slowly, as if bargaining with time.
The wind comes from across the river, carrying the damp scent and an indescribable chill.
When I caught that scent, my heart suddenly tightened.
The river has always been there.
It’s neither hurried nor slow, like a line that has grown used to silence, dividing the town into two.
When we were kids, we used to say that the other side of the river was a different world.
I've only just realized that the so-called "other side" isn't just about geography, but the part of the heart we're unwilling to touch.
When I got to the bridge, I stopped.
The wooden planks on the bridge have been replaced, and the railing has been repainted, but the stone at the bridgehead remains.
There is a crack in the rock, like a slender mouth that will never close.
When I was little, I always loved sitting here for a while, listening to the sound of the water, and waiting until it got dark to go home.
I remember back then I wasn't afraid of the dark.
Right now I'm standing here, but it feels as if someone is watching me from behind.
When I turned around, there was nothing at all.
There is only one dog under the street lamp.
It's black, with short fur, but its eyes are very bright.
It stood neither close nor far, as if deliberately keeping its distance.
It didn’t bark, nor did it wag its tail. It simply watched me quietly.
I originally planned to go around it, but it moved forward two steps, then stopped again, as if asking, “Do you remember me?”
I don't recognize it.
I wouldn't dare say that I don't know him either.
Because at that moment, I suddenly realized that in this town, many of the things I thought I didn’t know might actually know me.
Whose family are you from?
I asked softly.
Of course, the dog didn't answer.
It simply turned around and slowly walked toward the town.
I hesitated for a moment, but I still followed.
It's not that I like dogs, but that it walks with such certainty, as if it knows where I'm headed.
We walked through a very narrow alley. At the end of the alley there was an old lamp, and a tricycle was parked beneath it.
A white cat is sitting beside the car.
It curled its body up tight, its tail wrapped around its front paws, looking like a clean, neat shadow.
Upon hearing the footsteps, it raised its head, its gaze cold, but it was not afraid.
It glanced at the black dog, then at me again, as if judging whether I was the person who was supposed to show up.
I couldn't help but laugh a little: "Even cats and dogs are coming to greet me now?"
The white cat didn't move.
The black dog didn't move either.
At that moment, there was a strange quiet in the air, as if all the sounds were waiting for me to say the wrong thing.
I hid my smile and whispered, "I'm just back for a few days."
The white cat blinked once.
That movement was very slow, as if it were saying, 'Do you think you can decide to stay only a few days?'
The black dog continued to move forward.
I took two steps, and the white cat jumped off the car as well, then followed behind.
It moves very quietly, almost without a sound.
The black dog walked with a steady gait, as if on patrol.
None of the three of us spoke, but I felt as if they were communicating in a language I couldn't hear.
I suddenly remembered something from my childhood.
That summer was exceptionally hot.
I followed the adults to the riverbank.
People are arguing on the bridge, and their voices are loud.
I remember standing far away, but I could still hear my own heartbeat.
Then the grown-ups pulled me away, telling me not to look or ask.
On the way home, I kept looking back, but the tree shadows on the far side of the river grew darker and darker, as if they had swallowed something.
At the time, I thought it was just adults' business and had nothing to do with me.
But I also remember that after that day, someone at home grew very quiet.
Some people no longer mention a certain name.
Some places started closing early.
The river is still the same river, but we won’t just go sit by the bridge anymore.
Now, the direction the black dog is taking me is the very road I never dared to walk as a child.
I stopped in my tracks.
The black dog looked back at me.
Its gaze isn't like that of an ordinary dog; it's more like someone waiting for me to make a decision.
I don't want to go over there.
I said.
A white cat stood to the side, its tail swishing gently, as if it were laughing at me.
It didn’t make a sound, but that slight movement was more piercing than any words.
The black dog didn’t hurry me along; it just stood there.
A few seconds later, it turned around, walked up to my feet, lightly nudged my pant leg with its nose, and then took another step forward.
That touch was very light, yet it felt like a hand.
I took a deep breath and kept going.
The road keeps narrowing as you go, and the walls on either side grow taller.
In the distance, there’s a small shop lit up. A string of wind chimes hangs at the doorway, and when the wind blows, they produce a bright, crisp sound.
As I approached, I saw an old woman sitting inside the shop.
She looked up, saw me, and there was no surprise on her face; instead, it was as if she had known all along that I would come.
Her eyes were cloudy, yet steady.
She glanced at the black dog, then at the white cat, and only then did she look at me.
You're back?
She said.
I nod. "Grandma Wang... do you still remember me?"
She smiled briefly, a short laugh. “Of course I remember.”
You weren't this tall when you left.
I don't know how to respond.
There are so many things I want to say, but I can't bring myself to say them.
The old lady didn't pressure me either—she simply set the teacup down and looked at me, as if waiting for me to say something.
The black dog lay by the door, as if guarding it.
The white cat jumped up onto the edge of the counter and sat up straight, as if it owned the shop.
Grandma Wang watched them, and there was no surprise in her eyes—only the calm that had grown habitual.
She whispered, "You've finally come back after all."
"I was just..." I wanted to say I was just passing through, or that I just wanted to stay for a few days, but by the time the words reached my lips, they came out thin and useless.
Grandma Wang didn't laugh at me.
She just spoke slowly, "You haven't forgotten what happened on the other side of the river, have you?"
My fingers tightened.
Steam rising from the teacup blurred my vision.
I want to deny it, but I find I don't even have the strength to deny it.
The black dog stirred at the door.
The white cat's tail hung down, brushing lightly along the counter, as if reminding me: don't say too much, don't say the wrong thing.
I looked at Grandma Wang, and only after a long while did I speak. "I'm back... I want to know what exactly happened that day."
Grandma Wang didn't answer right away.
She shifted her gaze to the window, which faced the river.
Night had fallen, and the surface of the river was barely visible; only a few glints of light remained, as if someone had hidden a knife in the water.
She whispered, "If you want to know the answer, don't just stand here."
My heart sank.
The black dog raised its head and looked at me.
The white cat's eyes, in the light, look like two cold points of light.
I understand.
On my very first day back, I was already taken to the edge of the bridge.

chapters.title: 第2章：镇子没有变
chapters.text:
我在王奶奶的店里坐了很久。

她没有继续问我，也没有立刻讲河那边的事。她只是给我倒了杯热茶，动作很慢，像是在给时间找一个合适的速度。黑狗趴在门口，一动不动。白猫坐在柜台上，眼睛半闭，像是在休息，可我知道它没有真的睡着。

“你现在住哪儿？”王奶奶终于开口。

“还没找好。”我说，“可能先住两天旅店。”

她点点头，没有多说什么。她看我的方式，让我有一种奇怪的感觉——不是好奇，也不是同情，更像是一种早就知道结果的平静。

我起身告辞的时候，白猫从柜台上跳下来，走到门口，又停下，回头看了我一眼。黑狗站起身，先我一步走了出去。

夜已经深了，镇子却没有完全睡着。路灯下偶尔有人影走过，脚步不快不慢，像是在遵守某种我已经忘记的节奏。黑狗走在前面，我跟在后面。白猫不紧不慢地跟着我们，始终保持着一点距离。

“你们不用送我。”我低声说。

他们当然没有回应。

旅店在河的这一边，离桥不远。柜台后面坐着一个中年男人，他抬头看了我一眼，又低头继续看报纸。

“住几天？”他问。

“先两天。”

他在本子上写了几笔，没有多问我的名字，也没有问我从哪儿来，仿佛这里的人都习惯了不问多余的事。我接过钥匙，上楼的时候，下意识回头看了一眼门口。

黑狗没有进来，只是站在路灯下。白猫坐在墙头，影子被灯拉得很长。它们没有要跟上的意思。

那一刻，我竟然有点失落。

房间不大，却很干净。窗户正对着河的方向，拉开窗帘，就能看见远处微弱的水光。我站在窗前，看了很久，直到灯光在水面上被风吹得断断续续，像一条快要消失的线。

我本来以为，回到这里会让我安心。可真正站在这个地方，我却发现自己比以前更清楚地意识到：有些东西，我从来没有真正离开过。

第二天早上，我被街上的声音吵醒。

有人在说话，有车经过，还有很轻的脚步声。我洗了把脸，下楼的时候，看见黑狗坐在门口，像是守了一夜。白猫不在。

“你们一直在这儿？”我问。

黑狗抬头看了我一眼，又低下头。

我走出旅店，沿着熟悉又陌生的街道往前。店铺一间一间开门，面孔却几乎都换了。有人向我点头，有人看了我一眼又移开目光。没有人显得惊讶，也没有人显得热情，仿佛我的出现既不重要，也不多余。

我走进一家小吃店。老板是个我不认识的女人。

“想吃什么？”她问。

“和以前一样吧。”我说完才意识到，她不可能知道我以前吃什么。

她看了我一眼，没有追问，只是随意给我端了一碗面。味道和记忆里的不一样，却又说不出哪里不同。我一口一口吃着，心里却一直空着。

吃到一半，白猫出现在门口。它没有进来，只是坐在外面的台阶上，像是在等我。

我结了账，走出去。它站起身，转身往桥的方向走。我没有犹豫，跟了上去。

白天的河看起来很普通。水不急，岸边的树影也很安静。桥上偶尔有人走过，车不多，风却比昨晚更冷。白猫走到桥头就停下了，没有像黑狗那样继续往前。

“你不走？”我问。

它看着河面，尾巴轻轻摆了一下，没有看我。

我站在它旁边，顺着它的目光看过去。河那边的房子显得很旧，墙上有斑驳的痕迹，像是被时间反复触碰过。那一刻，我突然意识到，我其实并不确定，自己想知道的究竟是什么。

我只是觉得，有些事情如果不亲眼看一眼，我这辈子都会被它们牵着。

黑狗不知道什么时候出现了。它站在我身后，距离不远不近。

“你们每天都会来这里吗？”我问。

白猫没有回应。黑狗也没有。

可我却明白了：这不是第一次。

我站在桥头，风从河面吹上来，带着潮湿的冷意。昨天王奶奶说的话在我脑中反复出现——“别只站在这边”。

“如果我过去，”我低声说，“你们会跟我一起吗？”

白猫转过头，看了我一眼。那一眼很短，却像是在衡量什么。随后，它跳下台阶，往桥上走了一步，又停住。

黑狗没有动。

那一瞬间，我突然明白，他们并不是在带我走某一条路。真正要不要过去，从一开始，就不是他们能替我决定的事。

桥上的风铃响了一下，声音很轻。

我深吸一口气，向前走了一步。

就在我踏上桥面的那一刻，白猫没有继续往前。它转身，坐回桥头，静静地看着我。黑狗也停在原地，没有跟上。

我站在桥上，第一次清楚地意识到：
有些路，只能一个人走。

河水在脚下流动，声音很低，却从未停过。

我不知道等我走到那一边，会看见什么。
我只知道，如果我现在不走，这条路可能会在我心里存在一辈子。

我没有回头。

en_sentences.en: I sat in Grandma Wang's shop for a long time.
She didn’t press me further, nor did she immediately bring up what was happening across the river.
She just poured me a cup of hot tea, moving slowly, as if she were trying to find the right pace for time.
The black dog is lying at the door, motionless.
A white cat sits on the counter, its eyes half-closed, as if resting, but I know it's not really asleep.
Where do you live now?
Grandma Wang finally spoke.
I haven't found it yet.
I said, "Maybe we should stay in a hotel for two days first."
She nodded, not saying much.
Her way of looking at me gave me a strange feeling—neither curiosity nor pity, but more like a calm that comes from knowing the outcome all along.
As I stood up to say goodbye, the white cat jumped down from the counter, walked to the doorway, paused again, and looked back at me.
The black dog stood up and went out ahead of me.
The night was already deep, but the town hadn't quite fallen asleep.
Under the streetlight, a silhouette occasionally passes by, its steps neither fast nor slow, as if following a rhythm I have long forgotten.
The black dog walks in front, and I follow behind.
The white cat followed us at a steady pace, neither fast nor slow, always keeping a little distance.
You don't have to see me off.
I spoke softly.
Of course they didn't respond.
The inn is on this side of the river, not far from the bridge.
A middle-aged man sat behind the counter. He looked up at me for a moment, then lowered his head and continued reading the newspaper.
How many days are you staying?
He asked.
The first two days.
He wrote a few lines in the notebook, not bothering to ask my name or where I came from, as if the people here were used to not asking unnecessary questions.
I took the key, and as I went upstairs, I instinctively glanced back at the doorway.
The black dog didn’t come in; it just stood under the street lamp.
A white cat sits on top of the wall, its shadow stretched long by the lamp.
They have no intention of keeping up.
At that moment, I unexpectedly felt a little disappointed.
The room isn't big, but it's very clean.
The window faces the river. When you draw back the curtains, you can see the faint shimmer of water in the distance.
I stood at the window, watching for a long while, until the lights on the water flickered in the wind, like a line that was about to vanish.
I had originally thought that returning here would put me at ease.
Yet, as I stand in this place, I realize more clearly than ever before that there are some things I have never really left behind.
The next morning, I was awakened by the sounds of the street.
Someone is talking, a car passes by, and there are very faint footsteps.
I washed my face, and as I went downstairs I saw a black dog sitting at the door, as if it had been guarding all night.
The white cat isn’t here.
Have you all been here the whole time?
I asked.
The black dog looked up at me for a moment, then lowered its head again.
I stepped out of the hotel and walked ahead along streets that were both familiar and unfamiliar.
Shop after shop opened, but almost all the faces had changed.
Some people nodded at me, while others glanced at me and then looked away.
No one seemed surprised, and no one seemed enthusiastic, as if my presence didn’t matter and wasn’t superfluous.
I walked into a snack shop.
The boss is a woman I don't know.
What would you like to eat?
She asked.
Same as before, okay?
Only after I finished speaking did I realize she could not possibly know what I had eaten before.
She glanced at me, didn’t ask any questions, and simply brought me a bowl of noodles.
The taste isn’t the same as I remember, yet I can’t say where it’s different.
I ate bite after bite, but my heart felt empty the whole time.
Halfway through my meal, a white cat appeared at the door.
It didn't come in; it just sat on the steps outside, as if waiting for me.
I paid the bill and walked out.
It stood up, turned around, and walked toward the bridge.
I didn't hesitate and followed them up.
The river looks ordinary during the day.
The water is calm, and the shadows of the trees along the shore are very still.
There are occasional pedestrians on the bridge; there aren’t many cars, but the wind is colder than last night.
The white cat stopped at the bridgehead, not continuing forward as the black dog did.
Aren't you leaving?
I asked.
It looked at the surface of the river, its tail swishing gently, and it didn’t look at me.
I stood beside it and looked in the direction it was looking.
The house on the other side of the river looked very old, with mottled marks on its walls, as if time had touched them again and again.
At that moment, I suddenly realized that I wasn't actually sure what it was that I wanted to know.
I just feel that there are some things that, if I don't see them with my own eyes, will pull me along for the rest of my life.
The black dog appeared at some point.
It stands behind me, at a distance neither far nor near.
Do you come here every day?
I asked.
The white cat didn't respond.
There isn't a black dog either.
But I realized that this wasn't the first time.
I stand at the edge of the bridge, the wind rising from the river and carrying a damp chill.
What Grandma Wang said yesterday keeps echoing in my mind—"Don't just stand here."
"If I go back," I whispered, "will you all come with me?"
The white cat turned its head and glanced at me.
That glance was brief, yet it seemed to be weighing something.
Then it jumped down the steps, stepped onto the bridge, and stopped again.
The black dog didn't move.
In that moment, I suddenly realized that they weren’t leading me down a single path.
From the very beginning, whether I should go or not wasn’t something they could decide for me.
The wind chime on the bridge rang once, its sound very soft.
I took a deep breath and stepped forward.
The moment I stepped onto the bridge deck, the white cat didn't go any further.
It turned around, sat back on the edge of the bridge, and watched me quietly.
The black dog also stopped in its tracks and didn't catch up.
I stood on the bridge, and for the first time I realized clearly that some paths can only be walked alone.
The river flows beneath my feet, its sound soft, yet it has never ceased.
I don't know what I'll see when I get to the other side.
All I know is that if I don't walk away now, this path could stay in my heart for a lifetime.
I didn't look back.

chapters.title: 和小雨一起买晚饭
chapters.text:
“今晚小雨你想吃什么？”
“我有点饿，但不想吃太油的。”
“那我们做点简单的吧，小雨，比如鸡肉和蔬菜。”
“听起来不错，家里还有米吗？”
“有一点，不过不多，小雨，可能要再买一袋。”
“那顺便买点鸡蛋吧，明天早上想做早餐。”
“好，那我去拿鸡肉，小雨你去看蔬菜，好吗？”
“可以，你要不要也买点水果？”
“好主意，小雨，苹果和香蕉都挺方便的。”
“那就这些吧，结账以后我们就回家做饭。”

en_sentences.en: Xiao Yu, what do you want to eat tonight?
I'm a bit hungry, but I don't want to eat anything too greasy.
Then let's keep it simple, Xiaoyu—like chicken and vegetables.
That sounds good. Do we have any rice left at home?
There's only a little left, but not much. Xiaoyu, we may need to buy another bag.
Then pick up some eggs while you're at it; I want to make breakfast tomorrow morning.
Okay, then I'll go get the chicken. Xiaoyu, you check the vegetables, okay?
Okay, would you like to buy some fruit as well?
That's a good idea, Xiaoyu. Apples and bananas are both quite convenient.
That's about it. Once we've paid, we'll go home and cook.

“小雨，跟你说话，我觉得特别舒服。”
“小雨，你对我来说真的很重要。”
“小雨，不管今天好不好，有你就够了。”

“小雨，我真的很珍惜你。”

Xiaoyu, with you by my side, I feel at ease every day.
Xiaoyu, whenever you smile, I forget all my troubles.
Xiao Yu, thank you for always caring about me and looking after me.
Xiaoyu, talking to you makes me feel really comfortable.
Xiao Yu, you mean a lot to me.
Xiaoyu, no matter how today turns out, just having you is enough.
Xiaoyu, I want to stay by your side and walk with you all the way.

chapters.title: 时间与日常
chapters.text:
“现在几点了，小雨？”
“刚七点半，我们还来得及。”
“你一般几点起床？”
“工作日我六点半起，周末会晚一点。”
“那我们几点出门比较好？”
“八点之前吧，这样路上不会太堵。”
“你今天有没有时间一起吃午饭？”
“有，大概十二点左右我就有空。”
“晚上我们几点见面？”
“七点吧，太晚了我会有点累。”

en_sentences.en: What time is it now, Xiaoyu?
It's just past seven-thirty, and we still have time.
What time do you usually get up?
On weekdays I get up at 6:30, and on weekends I sleep in a bit later.
What time do you think would be best for us to leave?
Let's do it before eight. That way there won't be too much traffic.
Are you free to have lunch together today?
Yes. I'll be free around twelve.
What time should we meet tonight?
Seven o’clock, then. It’s getting late, and I’ll be a little tired.
